description: From Middle English birthe (1250), from earlier burthe, burde, from Old Norse burðr, byrd (Old Swedish byrth, Swedish börd), replacing Old English ġebyrd (rare variant byrþ), equivalent to bear +‎ -th (compare also berth). The Old Norse is from Proto-Germanic *burdiz (compare Old Frisian berde, berd); Old English ġebyrd is from prefixed *gaburþiz (compare Dutch geboorte, German Geburt), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰr̥tis (compare Latin fors (“luck”), Old Irish brith), from *bʰer- (“to carry, bear”). More at bear.

entries.meaning: A familial relationship established by childbirth.
examples: Her birth father left when she was a baby; she was raised by her mother and stepfather.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The process of childbearing; the beginning of life.

examples: Intersex babies account for roughly one per cent of all births.

entries.meaning: (countable) A beginning or start; a point of origin.
(uncountable) The circumstances of one's background, ancestry, or upbringing.
examples: He was of noble birth, but fortune had not favored him.

description: From Middle English birthen, birðen, from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: birth (third-person singular simple present births, present participle birthing, simple past and past participle birthed)

entries.meaning: To bear or give birth to (a child).
